steps.name: deck
steps.label: Select a deck
steps.description: Standard decks are best for tricks and skateparks. Cruiser decks are similar to a standard deck, but typically with only a rear kicktail, making them ideal for short commutes. Old school decks are typically wider and longer than a standard deck. The longboard, is intended for long distances, high speeds, and downhill riding.

steps.name: trucks
steps.label: Choose your trucks
steps.description: Trucks are a huge determiner of how your board will ride. A standard kingpin will give you a sharper response, while a reverse kingpin makes for a more stable ride. There are also drop through trucks that are mostly seen on longboards. The purpose of the drop through is to lower the center of gravity, making it more stable for higher speeds.

steps.name: wheels
steps.label: Select your wheels
steps.description: The main differences between wheels are size, hardness, and grip. Harder smaller wheels are best in skateparks and bigger, grippier wheels handle better for distance and commute rides.

steps.name: risers
steps.label: Add risers
steps.description: While risers are not necessary, they add height between the board and trucks, giving the rider more clearance for sharper, snappier turns and tricks.

steps.name: griptape
steps.label: Grip tape
steps.description: You'll want to add some grip to your deck. The standard route is griptape, but you can also use a spray-on grip. This is typically for preserving the asthetics of the board.
